CatDescriptText: Mrs. Bernice Reinert, office worker, Munhall and Mr. Francis Carragher, salesman, Lawrenceville, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column, published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, June 17, 1961, pg. 2 with question: "Do you think that courses in race relations should be taught in the public schools?  If so, in what grade do you think they should be taught first?"  Mrs. Bernice Reinert's answer reads: "I don't think it would hurt.  It could be done, but I don't think we have had race problems.  As I say, it could be taught and maybe around the fifth or sixth grade, because children at that age are beginning to look around and see what differences there are among them."  Mr. Francis Carragher's answer reads: "I think they should be taught.  It's difficult, however, to say when this should begin.  It depends on the individual, when he's able to comprehend....to grasp...this subject.  Perhaps high school would be better than elementary school..."
